title: Re: rorie1983.com
content:
There's one slight problem with the site:
[quote]Quote:[hr]You will need a resolution of 1024x768 to view the site properly[hr][/quote]
I wonder how many people still use that res? Admittedly I've had to cut back to 1600x1200 recently (my second monitor is in pieces on the floor until I figure out what was making that sparking noise) but a common symptom of bad web design is that the page will only render correctly at a certain resolution.

You should use relative widths, like 50% or 100%, so that elements in your site design will adjust correctly regardless of the screen resolution. Don't you find it annoying when you come across a window that you want to make bigger, but the program won't let you resize it? Don't let your website suffer from the same problem [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: rorie1983.com
content:
Actually where I work 1024 is pretty much the standard resolution.
Even people with brand new high res flat screens prefer 1024 over whatever nicer number the screen is intended to be used with.
Of course this makes things look fuzzy, and if it's a wide screen it'll also make things look stretched, but apparently either my eyes are much better than other evidence makes me believe they are, or a lot of people have poor eyesight, or at least colleagues.
Sometimes using large icons and larger font sizes will do the trick, but sometimes they still prefer 1024.

As for the site... the menu on the left is a bit hard to read in my opinion.
The easiest fix I'd suggest is to add some more space inbetween the individual letters.
Impact is very vertically oriented, and it makes it hard to make out the individual letters.

As for the 1024 resolution, I'd personally also make the site adapt to the viewer's resolution, which luckily shouldn't be too hard with the current layout.Retodon8
